title: Understanding Equilibrium Constants
text: The equilibrium constant, K, for a reaction is a ratio of the concentrations of products to reactants, each raised to the power of their coefficients in the balanced equation. For gases, we use partial pressures, denoted as $$K_p$$.

title: Identifying the Phases
text: In the given reaction, identify which substances are in the gaseous phase and which are in the solid phase. Remember, only gases and aqueous solutions appear in the equilibrium expression.

title: Writing the Equilibrium Expression
text: Since only CO2 is in the gaseous phase, the equilibrium expression $$K_p$$ will only include the partial pressure of CO2. Solids like CaCO3 and CaO do not appear in the expression.

title: Formulating $$K_p$$
text: The equilibrium constant expression for the reaction is $$K_p=[CO2]$$. This is because the concentration of solids is constant and does not affect the equilibrium.

title: Finalizing the Expression
text: Ensure that your final expression for $$K_p$$ is written correctly, with $$K_p=$$ followed by the concentration of CO2 in brackets.
